data.title: On Soccer: Eddie Johnson's international career apparently isn't over yet
data.meta_description: Back with the U.S. national team, he scores both goals in Friday's 2-1 win over Antigua and Barbuda
data.text:
Remember Eddie Johnson’s record-breaking debut with the United States national team? He was a phenom, the type of goal scorer we were hoping would eventually develop one day from all those kids playing soccer on weekend mornings across the country.

There was the belief he would be the first of a new breed of U.S. forward, one who would be more technically and tactically gifted than the previous generation and a player who would elevate the national team to a level few teams in the world could match.

That’s a lot to expect of any player, and within a few years we realized that wasn’t going to be the case. Yet we keep making the same mistake with every player who scores a goal for the national team or in Major League Soccer who still has the word ‘teen’ attached to his age.

We’ve done it with Freddy Adu and Jozy Altidore and Juan Agudelo, and we’ll continue to do it with the next Under-17 player who shows promise as well.

Is it a bad thing to have that hope? Of course not. Maybe one day the U.S. version of Lionel Messi will be discovered. But until then we have to realize one thing about these players who don’t quite live up to unrealistic expectations at such a young age.

Their careers are far from over.

Which brings us back to Eddie Johnson. On Friday night, Johnson was making his first appearance with the U.S. national team in almost two and a half years, and was only on the roster because U.S. coach Jurgen Klinsmann had been disappointed with Altidore’s attitude and work ethic.

Klinsmann targeted Johnson for two reasons. He had been a consistent goal scorer with the Seattle Sounders since his return to MLS this year, and he was good in the air. Friday night, Johnson scored two goals — both on headers, including one in the final minute, when the Americans eked out a 2-1 World Cup qualifying victory over Antigua and Barbuda.

Johnson’s performance eased the pressure for tonight’s final qualifier against Guatemala in Kansas City, Kan., where the Americans need just a tie to advance to the final round of CONCACAF qualifying.

It may also have helped save Klinsmann’s job, since a failure to advance (and coming just seven months after the Under-23 team failed to qualify for the Olympics) might have caused the U.S. Soccer Federation to blow up the entire men’s program and start from scratch.

“We see a player that has matured a lot and knows now that he has a point to prove,” Klinsmann said after the game. “He gets that opportunity and knows that maybe at his age there might not be that many opportunities coming.”

Johnson, 28, didn’t have that maturity early in his career. He scored 37 goals in 51 international youth games with the U-17, U-20 and U-23 teams, signed a Nike Project-40 contract and was drafted at the age of 16 by FC Dallas in the second round of the 2001 MLS SuperDraft. He scored 24 goals in five years and was traded to Kansas City, where he scored 15 goals in 2007.

He had an even better beginning with the national team, where, at the age of 20, he became the first player in men’s national team history to score a goal in each of his first four appearances, three of which were qualifiers for the 2006 World Cup.

But things quickly went south. Following the 2007 season Johnson went to Europe, where he had stints with Cardiff City, Aris and Preston North End, where playing time — and goals — were hard to come by.

During that time he was brought into national team camp prior to the 2010 World Cup, but was one of the last cuts. Combined with an poor attitude, you had to wonder if his international career was over.

Perhaps sensing that, and with little prospects overseas, Johnson returned to MLS this year, where he was selected by the expansion Montreal Impact via the allocation process but immediately traded to Seattle, where he has prospered under veteran coach Sigi Schmid. Johnson has 14 goals in 26 games and is said to be more open and thoughtful and outgoing with the media.

He also has 14 goals with the national team, including 10 goals in 10 World Cup qualifiers, and could still make something of his international career. Perhaps just as important, he could light a fire under Altidore, who may be taking his place with the national team a little too much for granted.

In any case, Klinsmann has another forward in the player pool to choose from. Considering the poor strike rate up front in recent years, that can only be a good thing.

Brazil and Colombia will play a friendly Nov. 14 at 7:30 p.m. at MetLife Stadium. ... Christine Sinclair received a four-game suspension from FIFA for her conduct following Canada's 4-3 loss to the United States in the Olympic semifinals. She also was fined an undisclosed amount. "We feel like we didn't lose, we feel like it was taken from us," Sinclair said moments after the match. "It's a shame in a game like that that was so important, the ref decided the result before it started." ... The U.S. women's national team continues its Olympic victory tour Saturday against Germany at Toyota Park, home of the Chicago Fire. They play Germany again a week from today in East Hartford, Conn. ... France won the women's Under-17 World Cup, beating North Korea 7-6 in eight rounds of penalty kicks following a 1-1 tie. Ghana beat Germany, 1-0, in the third-place game. ... Ecuadorian clubs Emelec and Barcelona played a 1-1 tie in a friendly last week before 10,536 at Red Bull Arena. ... Some World Cup qualifying notes from Friday: Red Bulls midfielder Joel Lindpere played 90 minutes in Estonia's 1-0 loss to Hungary while defender Roy Miller played 90 minutes in Costa Rica's 1-0 victory over El Salvador ... Italy's 3-1 victory over Armenia was its 33rd match without defeat in World Cup and European Championship qualifying. ... In the Netherlands' 3-0 win over Andorra, Klaas Jan Huntelaar scored his 34th international goal to move one ahead of Johan Cruyff and one behind Ruud van Nistelrooy on the all-time Dutch list. ... In Greece's scoreless tie with Bosnia, midfielder Giorgos Karagounis earned his 121st cap, breaking a tie with former captain Theo Zagorakis for the most in Greece history. ... Germany forward Miroslav Klose scored his 65th career goal, leaving him three behind Gerd Mueller for the most in German history, in a 6-1 victory at Ireland. The loss tied the record for the worst home loss in Ireland history, matching the 5-0 defeat to Spain in 1931. ... Wayne Rooney scored two goals in Saturday's 5-0 World Cup qualifying victory over San Marino to raise his career total to 31, fifth on England's all-time list. Rooney passed Tom Finney, Nat Lofthouse and Alan Shearer, who each scored 30 international goals. ... Striker Olivier Occean was sent off in Canada's 3-0 victory over Cuba and will miss tonight's match against Honduras, which will decide whether Canada advances to the final round of CONCACAF qualifying. The day before the game, three Cuban players defected in Canada and tried to cross the border at Niagara Falls into the United States. ... Mexico's 5-0 win over Guyana was played at the Houston Dynamo's BBVACompass Stadium. Guyana was the home team, but the Guyanese federation sold the rights to the game to a Texas-based promoter. ... Belgium handed Serbia its first home loss in a World Cup qualifier in more than 10 years when it won, 3-0. ... Spain's 4-0 win at Belarus was its 24th straight qualifying victory, but no one in Spain was able to see it because no broadcaster in the debt-ridden country paid to televise the match. It was the first time a Spain match was not broadcast at home since 1983, when the team played at Malta. ... Cristiano Ronaldo will become the third Portuguese player to reach 100 caps when Portugal plays Northern Ireland today. Ronaldo, 27, trails Luis Figo (127) and Fernando Couto (110) on the all-time list. He also has 37 goals for Portugal, a mark bettered only by Pedro Pauleta (47) and Eusebio (41). ... Defending champion Zambia qualified for the 2013 African Cup of Nations with a 9-8 penalty-kick shootout victory over Uganda following a 1-1 tie. Powerhouse Nigeria, which failed to qualify for the last tournament, easily made it with an 8-3 aggregate victory over Liberia. The big disappointment was Cameroon, which, despite winning the second leg, 2-1, over the Cape Verde Islands, failed to make it for the second straight time, losing the aggregate series, 3-2. Cameroon has won the tournament four times but is not the soccer power it used to be. ... After recent embarrassing incidents involving John Terry and Ashley Cole, England will introduce a new code of conduct next month. Violators could be suspended from international play. ... Bolton, just 3-5-2 and in 18th place in the League Championship after being relegated from the English Premier League last season, fired coach Owen Coyle. ... Wonga, an online loan provider, signed a four-year contract to be Newcastle's new shirt sponsor, beginning next season. The company also will invest at least $2.4 million in the club's academy and local enterprise scheme helping teenagers find employment. Newcastle also will change the name of its stadium from Sports Direct Arena back to St. James' Park next season. ... Former Netherlands midfielder Edgar Davids has been hired by Barnet of the English fourth tier as a co-coach and, eventually, a player. Davids, 39, will share duties with Mark Robson, and will play when he gets into shape. ... Helmut Haller, who scored the first goal of the 1966 World Cup final, a game Germany lost, 4-2 to England in extra time at Wembley Stadium, died last week after a long illness. He was 73. Haller scored 13 goals in 33 games for Germany, including six at the 1966 World Cup. ... Catania midfielder Francesco Lodi signed a new four-year contract. ... Palermo striker Abel Hernandez will be out at least four months after tearing the cruciate ligament in his right knee in training while on international duty with Uruguay. ... UEFA banned Montpellier coach Rene Girard from one Champions League match for an obscene hand gesture at the Schalke bench after the teams tied, 2-2, Oct. 3. ... Montpellier midfielder Karim Ait-Fana will be out six months after rupturing ligaments in his knee in training. ... Werder Bremen captain Clemens Fritz will be out six weeks with a groin injury. ... Helmut Haller, who scored the first goal of the 1966 World Cup final, a game Germany lost, 4-2 to England in extra time at Wembley Stadium, died last week after a long illness. He was 73. Haller scored 13 goals in 33 games for Germany, including six at the 1966 World Cup. ... Alessandro Del Piero and Emile Heskey each scored their first goal in the Australian league when Heskey's Newcastle Jets beat Del Piero's Sydney FC, 3-2. ... Midfielder Jason Culina, sidelined the past 18 months with a knee injury, signed a one-year deal with Sydney FC. ... Swiss champion FC Basel fired coach Heiko Vogel and hired former Basel player Murat Yakin to replace him. Yakin was fired as coach of Lucerne in August. ... Former Egypt coach Hassan Shehata signed a one-year deal with Al Arabi of the Qatar Stars League.
